subject: [PoC] Filter ironic nodes by chassis
commit_message:
[PoC] Filter ironic nodes by chassis

Add a new config option [ironic]chassis_uuid (default it None).

If this uuid is set, given Nova Compute service with ironic virt-driver will
only report and manage Ironic nodes that belong to this Ironic chassis.

This of course does not solve all the Nova-Ironic integration problems,
and is aimed to be an example on how to run multiple Nova computes with
Ironic virt driver while the Nova scheduler re-design is not finished.

Still, with the patch proposed there is no resource over-reporting,
and compute failure domain is narrower.

Operators would need to manually create same number of Ironic chassis as
there are Nova computes with Ironic driver planned/deployed,
distribute Ironic nodes between these chassis and
make the compute<->chassis mapping in the Nova configs for said computes.

Introduce the memory bandwidth monitor

This patch defines the numa memory bandwidth monitor.
The monitor inherits itself from the existing monitor base class.

The monitor calculates the memory bandwidth by reading the PMU
counter values via PcP. The rate is determined by calculating
the difference between two consecutive reads of the driver API
divided by the time difference. This allows nova to have a control
over the time period to represent the bandwidth instead of storing
instantenous values.

The maximum memory bandwidth is reported in the rate format and hence
the above time difference calculation doesn't apply. The maximum
memory bandwidth is not expected to change unless new memory units
are plugged into the host.

subject: virt/hardware: Fix 'isolate' case on non-SMT hosts
commit_message:
virt/hardware: Fix 'isolate' case on non-SMT hosts

The 'isolate' policy is supposed to function on both hosts with an
SMT architecture (e.g. HyperThreading) and those without. The former
is true, but the latter is broken due to a an underlying implementation
detail in how vCPUs are "packed" onto pCPUs.

The '_pack_instance_onto_cores' function expects to work with a list of
sibling sets. Since non-SMT hosts don't have siblings, the function is
being given a list of all cores as one big sibling set. However, this
conflicts with the idea that, in the 'isolate' case, only one sibling
from each sibling set should be used. Using one sibling from the one
available sibling set means it is not possible to schedule instances
with more than one vCPU.

Resolve this mismatch by instead providing the function with a list of
multiple sibling sets, each containing a single core.

This also resolves another bug. When booting instances on a non-HT
host, the resulting NUMA topology should not define threads. By
correctly considering the cores on these systems as non-siblings,
the resulting instance topology will contain multiple cores with only
a single thread in each.

Check for usage of same Cephx ID as manila service

There is an issue that happens when access is granted to a manila share
using the same Cephx ID that Manila uses when it is communicating with
the Ceph backend (e.g. the identity specified by the cephfs_auth_id

driver that checks to see if the Cephx ID given is the same that Manila
is using for its communication with the Ceph backend. If that is the

Glance interface address, memcached override, and glance override.

Note: This should not result in any behavior changes in regular Kolla, just
Kolla-Kubernetes and only when you've overridden stuff in globals.yml

Allows override of interface address, memcached pools, and glance registry
host so that Kubernetes can do the right thing.

There are some significant architectural issues involved in memcached pooling
in the Kolla-kubernetes world.  Avoiding them right now.

Current working with this Kolla-Kubernetes globals.yml file:

api_interface_address: "0.0.0.0"

memcached_servers: "memcached"

Two tings to note:
 * This depends on a kolla-kubernetes patch, so that it won't be merged
   until it's safe for glance to bind to 0.0.0.0.  It's OK to bind to
   0.0.0.0 in the Kubernetes world because the network fabric controls
   access.
 * In Kolla-Kubernetes, the global.yml file doesn't do var substitution
   so you have to be explicit about the URLs, otherwise Keystone will
   look like it was provisioned but it won't quite be provisioned right.

commit_message:
Don't allow " " as key pair name

This patch fixes the bug where " " space character was accepted while
importing a new Key-Pair in the launch instance modal of the Horizon
Dashboard.
The regex used earlier: "^[\w\- ]+$" allowed spaces in the beginning and at
the end of the keypair which gave birth to inadmissable key-pair results.
Details on the modified variable KEYPAIR_NAME_REGEX:
^   Beginning. Matches the beginning of the string, or the
    beginning of a line if the multiline flag (m) is enabled.
\w  Word. Matches any word character (alphanumeric & underscore).
+   Plus. Match 1 or more of the preceding token.
(?: Non-capturing group. Groups multiple tokens together
    without creating a capture group.
[   Character set. Match any character in the set.
-   Character. Matches a "-" character (char code 45).
    Character. Matches a SPACE character (char code 32).
]
\w  Word. Matches any word character (alphanumeric & underscore).
+   Plus. Match 1 or more of the preceding token.
)
*   Star. Match 0 or more of the preceding token.
$   End. Matches the end of the string,
    or the end of a line if the multiline flag (m) is enabled.

When we snapshot a non-volume-backed instance, we create an
image in nova.compute.api.API._create_image and set some
values from the instance but 'size' isn't one of them.

Later in the virt driver's snapshot method, at least for
libvirt, it gets the snapshot image from the image API (glance)
and when using glance v1 (use_glance_v1=True) the _extract_attributes

response to the form that nova expects. This code assumes that
the 'size' attribute is set on the image, which for a snapshot image
it might not be (yet anyway). This results in an AttributeError.

This change defaults the size attribute value to 0 if it's not set.
If it is set, but to None, we still use 0 as before.

commit_message:
Allow policy file to not exist

Now that policy rules can be registered in code there is a desire to run
projects without a policy file. However oslo.policy assumed a policy
file would exist and would raise an error if it could not be found. This
changes that behavior to not error if a policy file is not found.

Because there are now tools which can generate policy files which list
the defaults, or list the effective policy there is no requirement that
a policy file be used in order to examine the policy that is in use. So
it should be possible to run without one.
